required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Validation of the Vektor Computational ECG Mapping System (vMap™) for Atrial and Ventricular Arrhythmias/Pacing

brief_summary.textblock: This is a retrospective, multi center clinical study collecting existing, de-identified subject data from medical records to be analyzed using an independent core laboratory to validate performance of a computational ECG mapping system (vMap™).

primary_outcome.measure: Rate of accuracy/agreement of vMap™ in correctly identifying the ventricular chamber/region of the arrhythmia for PCV and VT.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately post ablation procedure through approximately 6 months post ablation procedure, based on retrospective data collection eligibility criteria.

secondary_outcome.measure: Rate of accuracy/agreement of vMap™ in correctly identifying the chamber/region of the arrhythmia location for all arrhythmia types.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately post ablation procedure through approximately 6 months post ablation procedure, based on retrospective data collection eligibility criteria.

secondary_outcome.measure: Rate of accuracy/agreement of vMap™ in correctly identifying the segment of the arrhythmia treatment across all arrhythmia types.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately post ablation procedure through approximately 6 months post ablation procedure, based on retrospective data collection eligibility criteria.

intervention.description: Retrospective data will be collected from cases where successful ablation was completed.

study_pop.textblock: Adult patients with cardiac arrhythmia that have undergone successful ablation procedures.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Patient has one of the following clinical arrhythmia/pacing types:
- Atrial pacing
- Atrial fibrillation
- Ventricular pacing
- Premature ventricular complex
- Ventricular tachycardia
- Ventricular fibrillation
- Focal atrial tachycardia
- Premature atrial complex
- Atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia
2. Patient has undergone 'successful' routine, standard of care diagnostic electrophysiology (EP) study using intracardiac catheters as clinically indicated, guided by fluoroscopy and routine electroanatomic mapping, intracardiac echocardiography, and/or cardiac imaging such as CT or MRI.
3. Patient has 12 lead electrogram data of clinical rhythms recorded on electrogram recording system.
4. Patient has undergone a successful ablation procedure.
5. Arrhythmia type and atrial/ventricular characteristics can be abstracted from patient medical records.
6. Patient was between 22 and 100 years of age at time of EP study and ablation procedure.
Exclusion Criteria:
Patients with unstable coronary artery disease, confirmed intracardiac thrombus, active sepsis, complex congenital heart disease, dextrocardia, severe pulmonary hypertension, decompensated heart failure, a mechanical heart valve, myocardial infarction within 1 month of ablation, inability to induce arrhythmia, unacceptable ECG data quality, and/or data included in the device training dataset.

facility.name: University of California San Diego Health
